Authors: Robert Anthony Powers, Timothy Y. James
Title:
Mating and molecular studies of the Coprinellus disseminatus
species complex reveal cryptic species with pan-global biogeographic
patterns
Keywords:
Coprinellus disseminatus cryptic species holoarctic
biogeography
Abstract:
Coprinellus disseminatus sensu lato ( the fairy bonnet
mushroom) is a diminutive, common, saprotrophic mushroom-forming
basidiomycete, traditionally believed to have a cosmopolitan
distribution. Through mating studies and a three-gene phylogeny: ITS
barcode (nuc rDNA internal transcribed spacer, ITS1-5.8S-ITS2),
β-Tubulin and, RPB2 (nuclear second largest subunit of RNA polymerase
II) we show that Coprinellus disseminatus sensu lato is a species
complex comprised of at least three cryptic species with a distinct
biogeographic distribution. C. disseminatus sensu stricto displays a
Holarctic biogeographic distribution, with continental endemism in both
Europe and North America. A second cryptic species in the C.
disseminatus complex is formally described, Coprinellus tropicalis. C.
tropicalis has a circum-global, pantropical distribution, and shows
little evidence of continental endemism. In matings between homokaryotic
isolates, C. disseminatus and C. tropicalis are shown to be separate
biological species. An additional putative cryptic species, Coprinellus
sp. MICH-215668 known from two collections in Puerto Rico and Hainan,
China, is also discussed.
